discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
CompTIA "a dual-channel motherboard might have four DIMM slots arranged in color-coded pairs. Each pair represents one channel. For example, channel A might be color-coded orange and channel B color-coded blue. Each slot in a pair represents one of the two sockets in the channel (A1 and A2, for instance)."

Selected Answer: A
That is right. Dual-Channel is the correct answer since it is 4 slots with two different color codes. Quad-Channel comes with 8 slots and two different color codes.

Selected Answer: A
Dual-channel motherboard might have four DIMM slots arranged in color-coded pairs. 
Each pair represents one channel.

questions.question_text: A user on the marketing team uses various multimedia applications that consume a lot of memory. The user needs to install more RAM to run these applications effectively. When the user opens the computer case, the user sees four slots in two sets of colors. Which of the following memory types is MOST likely required?
Which of the following allows all VMs in a virtual environment to have RAM allocated for use?

discussion.content: Containerization is close but incorrect as it does not involve "Guest OS"s, thus not a VM. Resource pooling chooses how much of a physical resource to allocate to each VM

Selected Answer: D
Resource pooling makes the most sense because none of the other options deal with the allocation of hardware
correct Resource pooling

Selected Answer: B
802.11a only supports 5 GHz

b and g only support 2.4 GHz

ac supports 5 GHz, but is backwards compatible with 2.4 GHz

Selected Answer: B
B. 802.11ac

802.11ac is the standard that supports both 5GHz and 2.4GHz channel frequencies. It provides higher data rates and improved performance compared to earlier standards. While 802.11ac primarily operates in the 5GHz band, it is backward compatible with 802.11n and supports the 2.4GHz band for compatibility with devices that use that frequency.

comments.content: Go and check the table and you will see that it is only 802.11ac and 802.11ax has both 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz. If the option includes 802.11ax, I would have chosen 802.11ax.

discussion.content: No correct answer there

Wi-Fi 5 (802.11ac)

Wi-Fi 5 is designed to work only in the 5 GHz band. A dual band access point can use its 2.4 GHz radio to support clients on legacy standards (802.11g/n)

Wi-Fi 6 (802.11ax)
Wi-Fi 6 works in both the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands.

this is incorrect... if a consumer electronic states this, what is actually happening is they are relying on the 802.11n standard for their 2.4Ghz band

Selected Answer: B
From CBT Nuggets, which is a great resource: 

While technically 802.11ac does NOT support 2.4 GHz bands, in practice most 802.11ac routers are dual-band and can fallback to 802.11n if needed.
https://www.cbtnuggets.com/blog/technology/networking/when-to-use-802-11-a-b-g-b-nc-wifi-standards
Dual band antennas are available for 802.11ac

Selected Answer: B
Via CompTIA's book:
A - "The IEEE 802.11a standard uses the 5 GHz frequency band only"
B - "Wi-Fi 5 [802.11ac] is designed to work only in the 5 GHz band. A dual band access point can use its 2.4 GHz radio to support clients on legacy standards (802.11g/n). A tri band access point has one 2.4 GHz radio and two 5 GHz radios. Wi-Fi 5 allows up eight streams, though in practice, most Wi-Fi 5 access points only support 4x4 streams. A single stream over an 80 MHz channel has a nominal rate of 433 Mbps."
C - "The IEEE 802.11b standard uses the 2.4 GHz frequency band"
D - "The IEEE 802.11g standard offered a relatively straightforward upgrade path from 802.11b; uses the same encoding mechanism and 54 Mbps rate as 802.11a but in the 2.4 GHz band used by 802.11b and with the same channel layout. This made it straightforward for vendors to design 802.11g devices that could offer backwards support for legacy 802.11b clients."
it's b 802.11ac
@Digital 1785 I agree. None of these options here are correct. The only 802.11 standards that support both 2.4 and 5GHz frequencies are 802.11 n, and the newest standard 802.11 ax

questions.question_text: Which of the following 802.11 standards supports both 5GHz and 2.4GHz channel frequencies?

comments.content: Thanks for this explanation, I keep questioning myself with these wrong answer they provided T_T but glad we have these questions to practice with.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The cause of the issue is most likely related to the Domain Name System (DNS).

When the technician can ping servers by IP address but cannot ping by UNC path, it means that the laptop is able to connect to the network, but is having trouble resolving the names of the servers using DNS. The UNC path uses server names instead of IP addresses, so if the DNS is not configured correctly, the laptop will not be able to resolve the names and connect to the servers.

Therefore, the technician should verify the DNS settings on the laptop and ensure that the correct DNS server addresses are configured.
The answer should be A

Selected Answer: A
The cause of the issue is most likely related to the Domain Name System (DNS).

When the technician can ping servers by IP address but cannot ping by UNC path, it means that the laptop is able to connect to the network, but is having trouble resolving the names of the servers using DNS. The UNC path uses server names instead of IP addresses, so if the DNS is not configured correctly, the laptop will not be able to resolve the names and connect to the servers.

Therefore, the technician should verify the DNS settings on the laptop and ensure that the correct DNS server addresses are configured.

questions.question_text: A hardware technician is configuring a laptop, and the network administrator requires the network settings to be static. The technician successfully pings the servers by IP address but cannot ping the UNC path. Which of the following is the cause of this issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. The TV's HDMI-ARC port is not being used.

The most likely cause of the issue is that the technician is not using the TV's HDMI-ARC (Audio Return Channel) port. This port is specifically designed to send audio signals from the TV back to the soundbar, allowing for a single HDMI cable to be used for both video and audio. If the technician is using a different HDMI port, such as one labeled "HDMI IN," the soundbar will not receive any audio signals.
Never heard of ARC and I finished 3 courses, I'm not sure how you guys know this.
This ARC port is part of new sound bars. Just installed the ARC cable and sound is great.
ARC= Audio Return channel. Correct

questions.question_text: A technician has set up a new conference room with a TV and a video soundbar. The technician wants to test the system with a conference call. During the test, the TV speaker produces sound, but the soundbar does not. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of the issue?

choices.A: The volume on the TV needs to be turned up.
choices.B: The conference call needs to be unmuted for audio.
choices.D: The TV's HDMI-ARC port is not being used.
choices.C: An incorrect HDMI cable is being used.
